conclusion: The problem is about finding the power of an electromagnetic railgun when the projectile is launched.
Power is energy per unit time.

A railgun works by having a conductive projectile move between two parallel rails with current flowing through one rail, through the projectile, and back through the other rail, creating a magnetic field.
The Lorentz force propels the projectile forward, given by F = BIL.
Given: L = 0.5 m (rail length), d = 0.02 m (rail spacing), m = 0.02 kg (projectile mass), I = 10 A (current), B = 1 T (magnetic field).

premise: F = BIL = B * I * d = 1 T * 10 A * 0.02 m
conclusion: The force on the projectile is F = 0.2 N.
Power is work per unit time, which is F * v, where v is the velocity of the projectile.
The distance over which this acceleration occurs is the length of the rail, L = 0.5 m.

premise: v² = u² + 2as, where u = 0, s = L = 0.5 m, a = 10 m/s²
conclusion: v² = 10 m²/s², therefore v = sqrt(10) m/s.

premise: P = F * v = 0.2 N * sqrt(10) m/s

conclusion: Kinetic energy is (1/2)mv² = (1/2)*0.02 kg*(10 m²/s²) = 0.1 J.
Power is defined as work per unit time.

premise: The work done is 0.1 J over 0.3162 s.
